Phragmén-Lindelöf, subharmonic functions

Let Ω={(x,y)∈R2∣x>0, y>0}\Omega = \set{\p{x, y} \in \R^2 \mid x > 0,\ y > 0}Ω={(x,y)∈R2∣x>0, y>0} and let uuu be subharmonic in Ω\OmegaΩ, continuous in Ω‾\cl{\Omega}Ω, such that

u(x,y)≤∣x+iy∣,u\p{x, y} \leq \abs{x + iy},u(x,y)≤∣x+iy∣,

for large (x,y)∈Ω\p{x, y} \in \Omega(x,y)∈Ω. Assume that

u(x,0)≤ax,u(0,y)≤by,x,y≥0,u\p{x, 0} \leq ax, \quad u\p{0, y} \leq by, \quad x, y \geq 0,u(x,0)≤ax,u(0,y)≤by,x,y≥0,

for some a,b>0a, b > 0a,b>0. Show that

u(x,y)≤ax+by,(x,y)∈Ω.u\p{x, y} \leq ax + by, \quad \p{x, y} \in \Omega.u(x,y)≤ax+by,(x,y)∈Ω.
Solution.

Observe that

u(x,y)−(ax+by)≤u(x,y)≤∣x+iy∣u\p{x, y} - \p{ax + by} \leq u\p{x, y} \leq \abs{x + iy}u(x,y)−(ax+by)≤u(x,y)≤∣x+iy∣

for large (x,y)∈Ω\p{x, y} \in \Omega(x,y)∈Ω, by assumption. Recall that φ(z)=∣z∣k\phi\p{z} = \abs{z}^kφ(z)=∣z∣k is a Phragmén-Lindelöf function for Ω\OmegaΩ, where 0<k<20 < k < 20<k<2. In particular, k=1k = 1k=1 works. Thus, because u(x,y)−(ax+by)u\p{x, y} - \p{ax + by}u(x,y)−(ax+by) is subharmonic (uuu is subharmonic and ax+byax + byax+by is harmonic), it attains its maximum on the boundary.

On y=0y = 0y=0, our assumption gives u(x,0)−ax≤0u\p{x, 0} - ax \leq 0u(x,0)−ax≤0. Similarly, if x=0x = 0x=0, we have u(0,y)−by≤0u\p{0, y} - by \leq 0u(0,y)−by≤0 as well. Hence, u(x,y)−(ax+by)≤0u\p{x, y} - \p{ax + by} \leq 0u(x,y)−(ax+by)≤0 on all of Ω\OmegaΩ, i.e.,

u(x,y)≤ax+byu\p{x, y} \leq ax + byu(x,y)≤ax+by

on all of Ω\OmegaΩ.

For completeness, we will prove that φ(z)=∣z∣k\phi\p{z} = \abs{z}^kφ(z)=∣z∣k for 0<k<πβ−α0 < k < \frac{\pi}{\beta - \alpha}0<k<β−απ​ is Phragmén-Lindelöf function (PL function) for the sector Ω={α<Arg⁡z<β}\Omega = \set{\alpha < \Arg{z} < \beta}Ω={α<Argz<β}.

Let 0<k<k1<πβ−α0 < k < k_1 < \frac{\pi}{\beta - \alpha}0<k<k1​<β−απ​ and γ=α+β−α2=α+β2\gamma = \alpha + \frac{\beta - \alpha}{2} = \frac{\alpha + \beta}{2}γ=α+2β−α​=2α+β​ (this is the rotation needed to center the sector about the positive real axis). Set

ψ(z)=Re⁡((e−iγz)k1)=Re⁡(ek1Log⁡(e−iγz))=Re⁡(ek1log⁡ ∣z∣+ik1(Arg⁡(z)−γ))=∣z∣k1cos⁡(k1(Arg⁡(z)−γ)),\begin{aligned} \psi\p{z} = \Re\p{\p{e^{-i\gamma}z}^{k_1}} &= \Re\p{e^{k_1\Log\p{e^{-i\gamma}z}}} \\ &= \Re\p{e^{k_1\log\,\abs{z} + ik_1\p{\Arg\p{z}-\gamma}}} \\ &= \abs{z}^{k_1}\cos\p{k_1\p{\Arg\p{z} - \gamma}}, \end{aligned}ψ(z)=Re((e−iγz)k1​)​=Re(ek1​Log(e−iγz))=Re(ek1​log∣z∣+ik1​(Arg(z)−γ))=∣z∣k1​cos(k1​(Arg(z)−γ)),​

which is harmonic as the real part of an analytic function. Notice also that

−β−α2=α−γ<Arg⁡(z)−γ<β−γ=β−α2.-\frac{\beta - \alpha}{2} = \alpha - \gamma < \Arg\p{z} - \gamma < \beta - \gamma = \frac{\beta - \alpha}{2}.−2β−α​=α−γ<Arg(z)−γ<β−γ=2β−α​.

Hence,

k1(Arg⁡(z)−γ)∈[−k1(β−α2),k1(β−α2)]⊆(−π2,π2),k_1\p{\Arg\p{z} - \gamma} \in \br{-k_1\p{\frac{\beta - \alpha}{2}}, k_1\p{\frac{\beta - \alpha}{2}}} \subseteq \p{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}},k1​(Arg(z)−γ)∈[−k1​(2β−α​),k1​(2β−α​)]⊆(−2π​,2π​),

i.e., kkk is chosen so that the cosine term in ψ\psiψ is bounded strictly above 000. Thus, for zzz large,

φ(z)ψ(z)≤C∣z∣k−k1→z→∞0.\frac{\phi\p{z}}{\psi\p{z}} \leq C\abs{z}^{k-k_1} \xrightarrow{z\to\infty} 0.ψ(z)φ(z)​≤C∣z∣k−k1​z→∞​0.

Let uuu be subharmonic on Ω\OmegaΩ and continuous on Ω‾\cl{\Omega}Ω. Suppose further that u(z)≤Mu\p{z} \leq Mu(z)≤M on ∂Ω\partial\Omega∂Ω and satisfies u(z)≤Cφ(z)u\p{z} \leq C\phi\p{z}u(z)≤Cφ(z) for large zzz and some C>0C > 0C>0.

Let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 and set uε(z)=u(z)−εψ(z)u_\epsilon\p{z} = u\p{z} - \epsilon\psi\p{z}uε​(z)=u(z)−εψ(z). This is subharmonic since uuu is and because ψ\psiψ is harmonic. Then

uε(z)≤Cφ(z)−εψ(z)=−ψ(z)(ε−Cφ(z)ψ(z))→z→∞−∞.u_\epsilon\p{z} \leq C\phi\p{z} - \epsilon\psi\p{z} = -\psi\p{z}\p{\epsilon - C\frac{\phi\p{z}}{\psi\p{z}}} \xrightarrow{z\to\infty} -\infty.uε​(z)≤Cφ(z)−εψ(z)=−ψ(z)(ε−Cψ(z)φ(z)​)z→∞​−∞.

In particular, there exists R>0R > 0R>0 so that for large zzz, uε(z)≤Mu_\epsilon\p{z} \leq Muε​(z)≤M. Since B(0,R)∩ΩB\p{0, R} \cap \OmegaB(0,R)∩Ω is a bounded set, we may apply the maximum principle on uεu_\epsilonuε​ to see uε(z)≤Mu_\epsilon\p{z} \leq Muε​(z)≤M on B(0,R)‾∩Ω\cl{B\p{0, R}} \cap \OmegaB(0,R)​∩Ω. Hence, uε≤Mu_\epsilon \leq Muε​≤M on all of Ω\OmegaΩ. Sending ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0, we see that u≤Mu \leq Mu≤M on all of Ω\OmegaΩ, which completes the proof.
